docs.lead_paragraph: Tommy Harper, the former Red Sox player and coach who complained about a racial incident during the team's 1985 spring training and was fired after the season, was hired yesterday for a second stint on the team's coaching staff. Harper, 59, will work mainly with outfielders and on base running.
docs.abstract: Tommy Harper is named Boston Red Sox coach (S)

headline.main: Harper a Coach For a Second Time

docs.lead_paragraph: Pedro Martinez of the Red Sox has one more start scheduled before opening day, but he appears ready now. ''I feel like I could go nine easily,'' he said yesterday after striking out seven batters in six innings in Boston's 5-4 loss to the Minnesota Twins. ''I feel the best of the whole spring training today.''
docs.abstract: Pitcher Pedro Martinez of Boston Red Sox says he is ready to start season (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mo Vaughn tries hard to shackle his thoughts, but sometimes they just happen, like a home run that he doesn't try to hit. Vaughn is the cornerstone of a Red Sox team that is like a lost soul, meandering through life with no sense of direction. If Point A is where they are and Point B is where they want to be, the Red Sox seem to have no clue how to get there.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox first baseman Mo Vaughn expresses concern about direction in which team is headed after losing Roger Clemens and Jose Canseco; photo (M)

headline.main: Red Sox May Be Classified as a Lost Cause Before the Start of the Season

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox agreed yesterday to a one-year, $1.85 million contract with outfielder SHANE MACK, 33, who spent the last two seasons with Yomiuri of Japan's Central League. Mack, who was with Minnesota from 1990-94, hit .293 last season with 22 homers and 75 runs batted in. (AP)
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox sign one-year pact with Shane Mack, outfielder who spent last two seasons playing in Japan (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Roger Clemens makes his much-awaited return to the Red Sox rotation Friday night after recuperating from a right shoulder strain that kept him out for all of spring training and the first five weeks of the season. He will face Seattle, fresh off a three-game sweep of the Yankees, and the undefeated Chris Bosio (3-0). "I'll be the first one glad to see him out there on the mound, that's where he belongs," Boston first baseman Mo Vaughn said today. "He's going to help this whole staff with his presence."

docs.lead_paragraph: Butch Hobson, who could not turn around a team whose players admired him, was dismissed today as manager of the Boston Red Sox after three losing seasons. Although rumors of his dismissal circulated for the last two seasons, Hobson said he was surprised he was let go.

headline.main: Hobson Surprised as Red Sox Lower Boom

docs.lead_paragraph: Jason Leader, a cancer patient at Children's Hospital in Boston, was celebrating his 11th birthday. Boston's Mo Vaughn promised him by telephone to hit a home run for him. In the seventh inning of what turned out to be an 8-5 Red Sox loss to the California Angels on Saturday, Vaughn kept his promise. "I hope it gave him just a little more strength to push on, to keep going," Vaughn said today. "Guys today, athletes like myself, have some nerve getting a bad attitude, being angry about this or that."

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN ROGER CLEMENS TOES the mound, you can't take your eyes off him. Standing erect, he exhales deeply as his empty right hand falls politely to his side. Like a chubby-cheeked choirboy lifting an open hymnal, he raises the black Wilson mitt on his left hand to a resting place in front of his solemn game face. After a gentle rock backward, he reaches into his glove, as if to remove a bookmark, grasps the ball and, with a grimace and a grunt, commences the same windup that he had rehearsed before a full-length mirror after every Little League game. Clemens is a 6-foot-4-inch time machine, a throwback to an era when uniforms were baggy and throwing hard was everything, when the guy hurtling thunderbolts down from the mound was Cy Young or Walter Johnson or Bob Feller. His high hard ones rip across the ages, punching holes in fancy hitting theories and computerized strategies. In 1986, he struck out 20 batters in a single game, a major-league record. Grab a bat and feel the heat. Crowd the plate and he'll brush you back easy as spit. If the opposing pitcher plunks one of his mates, Clemens'll nail the next batter he faces. He even has a good old-fashioned monicker: the Rocket.

docs.lead_paragraph: Roger Clemens won a partial victory yesterday in a six-month war of words, but ended up the loser anyway. Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent upheld a five-game suspension and $10,000 fine imposed on the Red Sox pitcher by the American League president, Dr. Bobby Brown, effectively knocking Clemens from the mound for his scheduled start against Kansas City tomorrow night.

headline.main: Penalties Are Upheld by Vincent, and Clemens Starts to Sit

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox and their center fielder, Ellis Burks, decided to split their $750,000 difference, but not exactly right down the middle. Burks, who had sought $2.1 million through arbitration, signed a one-year contract yesterday that will pay him $1.825 million, which is $275,000 below his asking price and $475,000 above the Red Sox offer of $1.35 million.
